There are a few points in addition to those made by Colin and Yuri 
that ma=
y be informative:

1) It is not necessarily true that an arbitrary topology=
 takes 
longer to activate than a regular topology.  It depends on the 
top=
ology and the algorithm used for activation.  In fact, a lot of 
old resear=
ch into topology-and-weight-evolving ANNs used to cite 
activation times as=
 the *reason* for evolving topologies.

2) "Fast activation" is actually a =
pretty irrelevant factor in a lot 
of modern control tasks.  In a complex s=
imulated world, for example, 
the CPU time spent activating the network is =
trivial compared to the 
time spent in simulation and sensor calculations. =
 This is true in 
NERO, for example.  Even if the network activations in NE=
RO were 
improve by a multiple of 10 (i.e. 10x better) it would have a 
neg=
ligible effect on overall system performance.  The point is, the 
belief th=
at the time it takes to activate the network is a primary 
concern is somew=
hat antiquated. 

3) This is the most important point: NEAT is not just evo=
lving 
topologies in order to find "the perfect topology."  NEAT is using 
=
the fact that it is evolving topologies to make *evolution* fast.  
It does=
 that by minimizing the size of the networks being searched 
so that evolut=
ion is searching in a low-dimensional space, which 
leads to faster evoluti=
on.  Note that the *real* cost in 
neuroevolution is in the number of netwo=
rks that need to be 
evaluated in order to find a solution.  That is, the c=
ost of needing 
to evaluate many generations of additional networks dwarfs =
the cost 
of a slightly slower activation function.  One reason for that is=
 
that the cost of an evaluation includes a lot more than just network 
act=
ivation in many applications (as explained in #2).  Therefore, 
the point t=
o remember is that NEAT is using topology as a way to 
increase the power o=
f evolutionary search.  That is a powerful and 
important consideration ove=
r and above how fast network activation 
is.

ken
